stem: After reviewing the patient's electronic health record, match the ventilator settings or positioning strategy to the intended physiological effect in the management of ARDS.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
0600 SBAR for Mr. Jones, J. (DOB 03/15/1968) in ICU, Room 402.

Situation: Mr. Jones is a 56-year-old male admitted yesterday with severe ARDS secondary to aspiration pneumonia. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated.

Background: Patient has a history of hypertension and GERD. He presented with increased work of breathing, fever, and productive cough. Chest X-ray showed bilateral infiltrates. Initial ABG on room air: pH 7.28, PaCO2 55, PaO2 58, HCO3 24.

Assessment: Patient is sedated with propofol and fentanyl. Current vent settings: FiO2 60%, PEEP 10 cm H2O, TV 450 mL, RR 16. SpO2 is 90-92%. Peak inspiratory pressure is 35 cm H2O. ABG at 0530: pH 7.32, PaCO2 48, PaO2 65, HCO3 24. Coarse crackles auscultated bilaterally. Patient is on continuous enteral feeds at 40 mL/hr. Vasoactive agents are not prescribed at this time.

Recommendation: Consider increasing PEEP to improve oxygenation and decrease FiO2. Prone positioning may be beneficial if oxygenation does not improve. Monitor for signs of barotrauma and ventilator-associated pneumonia. Continue sedation and analgesia as needed. Strict aspiration precautions in place. Oral care q2h. Turn q2h. Continue monitoring vital signs and respiratory status closely.

0615: PEEP increased to 12 cm H2O per order. Will reassess ABGs in 1 hour.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Patient is intubated and sedated. Responds to painful stimuli.

Respiratory: Coarse crackles auscultated bilaterally. Chest expansion is symmetrical. Peak inspiratory pressure 35 cm H2O.

Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm. Peripheral pulses palpable.

Neurological: Pupils equal and reactive to light. GCS 8 (E1V2M5).

Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-distended. Bowel sounds present.

Skin: Skin warm and dry. No signs of pressure ulcers.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1.  Continuous mechanical ventilation: FiO2 60%, PEEP 12 cm H2O, TV 450 mL, RR 16.
2.  Sedation: Propofol continuous infusion at 20 mcg/kg/min.
3.  Analgesia: Fentanyl continuous infusion at 1 mcg/kg/min.
4.  Enteral nutrition: Continuous feeding at 40 mL/hr.
5.  Monitor vital signs and respiratory status q1h.
6.  ABG monitoring q1h.
7.  Strict aspiration precautions.
8.  Oral care q2h.
9.  Turn q2h.
10. Chest X-ray daily.
11. Increase PEEP by 2 cm H2O every hour until PaO2 > 70 mmHg, up to a maximum of 16 cm H2O. Notify provider if Pplat > 30 cm H2O.
12. Consider prone positioning if PaO2 remains < 70 mmHg with PEEP at 16 cm H2O and FiO2 at 60%.

rationale.correct: Increased PEEP improves oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse and increasing the surface area available for gas exchange. Decreasing tidal volume reduces lung injury by limiting alveolar overdistension (volutrauma). Prone positioning improves oxygenation by redistributing lung perfusion and ventilation, reducing atelectasis in the dependent lung regions.
rationale.incorrect: PEEP does not directly reduce lung injury or improve ventilation. Decreasing tidal volume does not directly improve oxygenation or ventilation. Prone positioning does not directly reduce lung injury or improve ventilation, though improved oxygenation can indirectly improve ventilation.

answerBreakdown.rationale: The ABG results show a PaO2 of 65 mmHg on FiO2 60% and PEEP 10. The order specifies increasing PEEP to improve oxygenation. PEEP increases alveolar recruitment and reduces atelectasis, thereby increasing the surface area for gas exchange and improving oxygenation.

In ARDS, reducing tidal volume to a lung-protective ventilation strategy aims to minimize alveolar overdistension and prevent ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI). This strategy prioritizes lung protection over achieving normal PaCO2 levels, accepting permissive hypercapnia.

The order states to consider prone positioning if PaO2 remains less than 70 mmHg with PEEP at 16 cm H2O and FiO2 at 60%. Prone positioning redistributes lung perfusion and ventilation, reducing atelectasis and improving oxygenation by promoting more uniform gas exchange.

clinicalPearls: In ARDS, a lung-protective ventilation strategy with low tidal volumes (6-8 mL/kg of ideal body weight) and permissive hypercapnia is often employed to minimize ventilator-induced lung injury.
PEEP should be titrated to achieve adequate oxygenation while avoiding overdistension of the alveoli (plateau pressure < 30 cm H2O).
Prone positioning is typically considered when patients with ARDS are not responding to conventional therapies to improve oxygenation.

questionTrap.trap: Students may incorrectly associate PEEP with improving ventilation because it can help to recruit more alveoli, but its primary effect in ARDS is to improve oxygenation by preventing alveolar collapse.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that PEEP's main role is to keep the alveoli open, which improves gas exchange and increases oxygenation. While this may indirectly help with ventilation, PEEP does not directly affect the removal of carbon dioxide.
